questions.text: The image below shows the hysterosalpingogram of a 37-year-old nulliparous woman. Identify the false statement about this finding.

choices.text: It is a thick walled structure on sonography
Tubal plicae are flattened on histology

questions.solution:
The given image shows bilateral hydrosalpinx. It appears as a thin-walled structure. 

A hydrosalpinx is a chronic cystic swelling of the fallopian tube that forms after a distal tubal obstruction. The tubes are enormously distended due to filling with clear serous fluid and become retort-shaped. On histology, the tubal plicae appear flattened. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during HSG. 

It is caused due to: 

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease 
  • Endometriosis 
  • Tuberculosis - tubercular salpingitis may also cause tobacco-pouch appearance, lead pipe appearance and pyosalpinx
  • Fallopian tube neoplasms (rare)

It can be an incidental finding during a pelvic exam or ultrasound. The patient may be asymptomatic, or present with infertility or chronic pelvic pain. 

On HSG, it appears as terminal sacculation and occlusion of both fallopian tubes with a normal uterine cavity. Usually, a thin-walled, hypoechoic, cystic structure is seen. However, it may appear as multiple hyperechoic mural nodules around the inner circumference of the tube creating a 'beads on a string' appearance.

Treatment:

  • Treat the underlying cause
  • Laparoscopic salpingostomy - in mild disease 
  • IVF recommended for women with infertility and severe hydrosalpinx

questions.text: A 33-year old P3L3 woman complained of intermenstrual bleeding. On speculum examination, a polypoid lesion was visualized in the cervix, which was confirmed with the ultrasound shown below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch with serial sonograms

questions.solution:
The above ultrasound image shows the presence of an endocervical polyp. The most appropriate treatment is avulsion using ring forceps.

Endocervical polyps are overgrowths of benign endocervical stroma covered by mucinous columnar epithelium. They appear as single, red, smooth elongated masses arising from the endocervical canal. Polyps range from a few millimeters to 2-3 cm in size and are more frequently seen in multiparas.

Endocervical polyps are usually asymptomatic, but also cause intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding or vaginal discharge. They are identified by inspection during a pelvic examination or during transvaginal sonography if they are located higher up.

They are typically benign. Premalignant or malignant transformation is rare. However, cervical cancer can also present as polypoid masses and can mimic these benign lesions.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic polyps usually don't need any intervention
  • Symptomatic:
    • Removal with ring forceps: The polyp is twisted repeatedly about the base of its stalk to strangulate its feeding vessels. With a repeated twisting, the base will narrow and avulse.
    • Removal with punch biopsy forceps for smaller polyps
    • Electrosurgical excision or hysteroscopic removal for polyps with thick stalks

After the removal of polyps, the base can be cauterized to prevent bleeding and recurrence rate. Every excised polyp should be sent for further histological examination to rule out malignancy.

questions.text:
Match the following methods of postcoital contraception to their doses.
Method Dose
1. Plan B A. Two 60 mg tablets to be taken at an interval of 12 hours 
2. Yuzpe B. 100µg ethinyl estradiol and 0.5 mg of Levonorgestrel, 2 tablets given 12 hours apart
3. Centchroman C. One 30 mg tablet 
4. Ulipristal D. Two 0.75mg tablets to be taken stat and after 12 hours 
5. Plan B-one step
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C.

Methods of Emergency contraception

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel (Plan B single step) 1.5mg tablet stat up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse
Levonorgestrel (Plan B- 2 steps) 0.75mg tablet stat and after 12 hours

Ethinyl estradiol 100 μg + Levonorgestrel 0.5 mg

(Yuzpe method)

 2 tablet stat and 2 tablets after 12 hours

Centchroman (Chhaya or Saheli)

  2 tablets(60 mg) to be taken twice in 24 hours, and within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal  30 mg within 5 days
Conjugated estrogen 15 mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5 mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUDs Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.Not suitable for rape victims

 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text:
A 45-year-old lady visits the Gynecology clinic for a routine check-up, during which her physician schedules a screening test for cervical cancer. Identify the correct statement about the test.
  1. Need not be deferred due to unexplained bleeding.
  2. 1 week of abstinence from intercourse is required.
  3. Ayre's spatula samples the endocervix.
  4. Cytobrush samples the ectocervix.
  5. The broom is rotated 5 times in the same direction.
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 5 are correct regarding the screening test for cervical cancer -the Pap/ Papanicolaou test.

Before the Pap test:

  • The Pap test should not be deferred due to unexplained discharge or unscheduled bleeding as they may be signs of cervical or other genital tract cancers.
  • Ideally scheduled to avoid menstruation. It is best performed around the time of ovulation.
  • Patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications for a minimum of 24 to 48 hours prior to the test.
  • Avoid touching the cervix before performing the Pap test, as dysplastic epithelium may get removed.
  • Ideally, confirmed cervicitis or vaginitis should be treated prior to the test

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula completing at least one full rotation. It predominantly samples the ectocervix. 
  • Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush, which is rotated only one-quarter to one-half turn after the ectocervix has been sampled.
  • A broom simultaneously samples both endo- and ectocervix. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended, since reversing direction may cause loss of cellular material. 
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides and fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

The image below shows the instruments used in cervical sampling: The broom, spatula, and cytobrush in order.

questions.text: A sterilisation procedure is being performed on a 32-year old P2L2 woman. During the procedure, the mid-portion of the fallopian tube is ligated and the intervening portion is excised. The proximal tubal stump is mobilized, buried and embedded into a pocket of myometrium. The distal tubal stump is buried between leaves of the broad ligament. Which of the following is the correct statement about this procedure?

choices.text: Cannot be done in conjunction with C section

questions.solution:
The procedure described is the Irving procedure which is a reliable method of sterilization. It involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

It is often done in conjunction with caesarian sections.

It is not a reversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision. Failure rates are less than 1 case in 1000 patients, making it a reliable method.

Uchida technique involves stripping the tubal serosa from the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, followed by ligation and excision of the stripped portion. The proximal stump is buried in the broad ligament while the distal stump is left open to the peritoneal cavity. This minimal tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Other methods of sterilization include:

  • Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:
    • Pomeroy's procedure: The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. It is surgically reversible.
    • Madlener's procedure: A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.
    • Kroener's technique: It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum. It is irreversible.
    • Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.
    • Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected between two clamps.
  • Laparoscopic techniques: 
    • Each fallopian tube is picked up near the isthmic end (2–3 cm away) and clipped or banded with silastic bands, Filshie clips, Hulka band, or falope silastic rings. It is a reversible technique.
  • Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 28-year-old female patient. On performing a per vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix that can be palpated is the anterior lip. What information does that convey about the position of the uterus and cervix?

choices.text: External os is directed forwards and downwards
Uterus is flexed backwards on cervix
External os is directed backwards and downwards
Uterus is directed backwards and downwards

questions.solution:
If the examining fingers palpate the anterior lip as the lowest part of the cervix, it means that the uterus is anteverted and the external os is directed downwards and backwards.

The normal position of the uterus is antiflexed and anteverted, ie the body of the uterus is flexed forwards on the cervix and the external os is directed downwards and backwards.

In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downwards and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix palpated is the posterior lip. The body of the uterus may also be flexed backwards in a retroverted uterus.

The angle of anteversion: The angle between the cervix and vagina. Normally it is 90 degrees. (Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

The angle of anteflexion: The angle between cervix and uterus. The angle is at the level of the internal os and is 120 degrees.

questions.text: A 47-year-old P1L1 lady presented with complaints of excessive bleeding during menstruation, and a feeling of heaviness in her lower abdomen. On examination, the uterus appeared enlarged with free adnexa. A hysterectomy was performed and the histopathological slide is shown below.  Which is the most common type of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of excessive menstrual bleeding, heaviness, and the enlarged uterus is suggestive of leiomyoma. The most common type is intramural leiomyoma. The stained histopathological image shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei.

Leiomyomas are benign uterine neoplasms, which are also known as myomas or fibroids. They are classified based on their location as:

  • Intramural or interstitial -most common, grows within the myometrial wall
  • Submucous- grows in the myometrium towards the endometrial cavity, and are covered only by a thin layer of endometrium
  • Subserous: grows from uterine serosa outwards towards the peritoneum
  • Other locations outside the uterus like the round ligament, the utero-ovarian and uterosacral ligaments, cervix, vagina, and the vulva.

When the leiomyoma is attached to a stalk, it is known as a pedunculated leiomyoma. Subserosal leiomyomas that attach themselves to nearby pelvic structures and derive vascular support are called parasitic leiomyomas.

Risk factors for developing fibroids include:

  • Increased risk:
    • Nulliparous women
    • Obesity
    • Hyper estrogenic states -endometriosis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma
    • African-American women.
  • Decreased risk in multiparous women.
  • Recent studies have shown no correlation between smoking and leiomyomas

Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic. However, affected women may complain of heavy menstrual bleeding, pain, pressure, or infertility.

Treatment:

  • Medical therapy: Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid
    • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
    • GnRH analogs
    • Agonists – goserelin, nafarelin
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
    • Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system
    • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Asoprisnil
  • Uterine artery embolization
  • Myomectomy
  • Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a Pap test, which showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, as per the Bethesda system of classification. This is the first Pap test she has undergone. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In a 26-year-old woman with a pap test showing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, the next step is reflex HPV testing.

Reflex HPV testing refers to HPV testing that is done in response to a specific result (such as abnormal cytology in this case). It is not performed if cytology is negative.

Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) is the most common cervical cytologic abnormality. They represent cells that suggest squamous intraepithelial lesions but do not fulfill all the criteria for them. The risk of progression to CIN 2 or 3 is low, but it may occur.

Management of ASC-US:

  • Women aged 21 to 24 years: Repeat cytology in 1 year. If the repeat Pap test result is abnormal, colposcopy should be done. Reflex HPV can be done in this age group. If the result is negative, they are followed up with cytology.
  • Women 25 years and older: Reflex HPV testing.
    • Reflex HPV test result is positive: Further evaluation with colposcopy.
    • Reflex HPV test result is negative: Follow up with a cotest (HPV test+ cytology) in 3 years.

Bethesda system of cytology reporting for squamous cell abnormalities:

  • Atypical squamous cells (ASC)
    • ASC-US - atypical cells of undetermined significance
    • ASC-H - cannot rule out a high-grade lesion
  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL)- includes CIN I
  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL)- includes CIN II, III
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: The absence of the SRY gene results in which of the following?

choices.text: Development of ovaries and Mullerian system

questions.solution:
The absence of the SRY gene results in the development of the ovaries and the Mullerian system.

In this situation, the gonads will develop into ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper part of the vagina. The master gene responsible for this is the WNT4 gene.

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, which has a sex-determining region called the SRY gene.

If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH) that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

Functions of SRY and WNT4:

SRY gene WNT4 gene

Development of the medullary/testes cords

The disappearance of medullary/testes cords

Formation of the tunica albuginea

Failure of formation of tunica albuginea

Failure of development of cortical/ovarian cords 

 Development of ovaries with typical cortical cords

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text:
A couple presented to the infertility clinic as they have been unable to conceive for more than a year. The lady has no abnormalities in her laboratory reports. The semen analysis report of her husband is given below. Which of the following findings indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia?

Appearance: Opalescent
Volume: 2 mL
pH: 7.5
Fructose: present
Sperm concentration: 14 million/mL
Morphology: 35% normal
Motility: 20% motile
No sperm agglutination was seen.
questions.solution:
The semen analysis finding of 20% motility (option B) indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia.

Asthenospermia refers to decreased sperm motility. Normally, at least 50% of them should show progressive motility. Causes of asthenospermia include prolonged abstinence, anti-sperm antibodies, a genital tract infection, or varicocele.

Various semen abnormalities include:

An acidic pH or lack of fructose: indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.

A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction, or retrograde ejaculation.

Oligospermia is defined by a sperm concentration of <15 million/mL, concentrations of <5 million/mL are considered severe oligospermia.

Azoospermia (absence of sperm in semen) occurs due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas deferens, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.

Teratospermia or teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents to the gynecology department with complaints of amenorrhea.  She had no history of cyclical abdominal pain, hormonal intake, radiation or chemotherapy, or any central nervous symptoms like visual disturbances or headaches. After a thorough physical examination, ultrasonography, karyotyping, and diagnostic laparoscopy, the diagnosis of Swyer syndrome was made. Which of the following is not congruent with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Normal development of the Mullerian system

questions.solution:
The karyotype of patients with Swyer syndrome (pure gonadal dysgenesis) is 46XY. The 45XO karyotype is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics due to absence of sex hormones.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with female external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, and absence of secondary sex characters.

Points to be considered while treating these patients:

  • Cyclical estrogen and progesterone can induce menstruation
  • As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.
  • Streak gonads may undergo malignant transformation and develop into germ cell tumors. Hence, they have to be removed prophylactically.
  • Hormonal replacement therapy also has a role in maintaining the bone health of these patients
  • Genetic counseling has to be offered to the affected individuals and their family members.

 

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding and was diagnosed as a case of carcinoma cervix stage IA1 after evaluation. She was treated with a modified radical hysterectomy. Which of the following structures are not removed?
questions.solution:
In modified radical hysterectomy/Type II hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are not removed. They are ligated at the level of the ureter. 

Structures removed in Type II hysterectomy:

  • Uterus
  • Cervix
  • Proximal 1-2cm of the vagina
  • Parametrial and paracervical tissue medial to the ureter
  • Pelvic nodes

Indications:

  • Stage I A1 cervical cancer with positive margins following conization, but have insufficient cervix to repeat conization.
  • Stage I A1 with lymphovascular space invasion
  • Stage I A2 cervical cancer
  • Occasionally, it may be performed in
    • Preinvasive or micro-invasive disease when a more invasive lesion cannot be excluded
    • Selected stage IB1 disease with < 2 cm lesion
    • Small central post-irradiation recurrences

Main differences between a modified radical hysterectomy (type II) and radical hysterectomy (type III):

  Modified radical hysterectomy Radical hysterectomy
Uterine artery Ligated at the level that it crosses the ureters Ligated at the origin from the internal iliac artery
Cardinal ligaments Medial half of cardinal ligaments resected Cardinal ligaments divided at the sidewall
Uterosacral ligament  Divided midway between uterus and sacrum Divided at sacrum
 Vagina 1-2cm of proximal vagina removed >2cm of upper vagina removed

 

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Among the given instruments 1, 2, and 3 - Sim's uterine curette, Hegar's dilators, and Simpson's uterine sound are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: It is used for menstrual regulation. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A woman was diagnosed with Stage 3 gestational trophoblastic neoplasia as per the classification by the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO). Which of the following images represents her stage?
questions.solution:
According to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), metastases to lungs are considered stage III gestational trophoblastic neoplasia(GTN), represented by image 3.

FIGO Stage  Extent
Stage I   GTN confined to the uterus

Stage II 

 GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures (adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III  GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV  All other metastatic sites

 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma 

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 35-year old lady came to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of foul-smelling, frothy vaginal discharge. A fresh sample of the discharge is taken and 10 percent potassium hydroxide is added to it. This releases a strong fishy odor. Which of the following conditions can be the etiology of the discharge?
  1. Candidiasis
  2. Trichomonas vaginalis
  3. Bacterial vaginosis
  4. Chlamydia
  5. Gonorrhea
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2 and 3.

The test described is the Whiff test, which is positive in Trichomonas vaginalis infections and bacterial vaginosis.

The whiff test is performed by the addition of 10 percent potassium hydroxide (KOH) to a fresh sample of vaginal secretions. In a positive test, it releases volatile amines that have a fishy odor. With bacterial vaginosis, the vaginal pH is > 4.5, as a result of diminished acid production by bacteria. Trichomonas vaginalis infection is also associated with anaerobic overgrowth and the production of amines. Thus, women diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis should have no microscopic evidence of trichomoniasis.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an alteration in the normal vaginal flora, where a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, where at least three of the four following criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

The presence of both clue cells and a positive Whiff test result is pathognomonic of bacterial vaginosis, even if asymptomatic. It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

Trichomonas vaginalis is an infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. On examination, the vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

It is treated with metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose (Standard treatment) or tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis

Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight woman presents with complaints of irregular periods for the last year. Physical examination revealed a BMI of 32 kg/m2 with signs of hirsutism. Pelvic sonographic findings show multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Centrochroman is not used in the treatment of PCOD. 

PCOD is attributed to obesity, smoking, and poor diet. The affected ovary or ovaries have cysts (12 or more) that are composed of atretic follicles, coupled with theca and stromal cell hyperplasia.  

Symptoms of PCOD include hirsutism and acne (due to hyperandrogenism), anovulation followed by amenorrhea, or heavy menstrual or intermenstrual bleeding.

Diagnosis is made by pelvic ultrasound which shows "necklace" appearance. Endomtrial hyperplasia may also be present. 

Treatment of PCOD includes lifestyle modification such as smoking cessation, diet, and exercise with a focus on weight reduction, combined oral contraceptives to regularize menstrual cycles and decrease androgen levels. 

To treat hirsutism, 5α-reductase inhibitors like finasteride are effective; eflornithine hydrochloride cream prevents hair growth.
 
Clomiphene is the first line of treatment for women with infertility. It may be combined with dexamethasone to improve the fertility rate.

Metformin treats the root cause of PCOS, rectifies endocrine and metabolic functions, and improves the fertility rate. It is used as an insulin sensitizer and induces spontaneous ovulation.

Surgery is indicated when medical therapy fails, when there is a history of previous pregnancy losses, when there is infertility, or when hyperstimulation occurs. Surgery comprises of laparoscopic ovarian drilling of not more than 4 cysts in each ovary by laser or unipolar electric cautery. It improves fertility for a period of one year. 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text:
You are a gynecologist with a special interest in hormone replacement therapy (HRT). Among the following patients, to whom would you avoid prescribing HRT?
  1. A 35-year-old woman who has undergone total abdominal hysterectomy+bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
  2. A 65-year-old woman having hot flushes with undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  3. A 57-year-old woman having hot flushes and risk factors for developing osteoporosis
  4. A 62-year-old woman with atrophic vaginitis and a history of myocardial infarction 10 months ago
  5. A 52-year-old woman with irritability and hot flushes, with a history of deep vein thrombosis in her previous pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is contraindicated in cases 2, 4, and 5.

HRT involves the cyclical administration of estrogen and progesterone, where estrogen is administered for 25 days followed by a progestin for 10-12 days. Re-evaluation for further need for HRT is done every 6-12 months. The progestin is added to lower the risk of developing endometrial cancer.

Contraindications for HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal bleeding from the genital tract
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer, or estrogen-dependent neoplasias
  • Active or previous history venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic diseases such as stroke or myocardial infarction
  • Liver or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of HRT
  • Known or suspected pregnancy

Indications for HRT:

  • Therapeutic:
    • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency- vasomotor symptoms, vaginal atrophy
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic: High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as
    • Cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
    • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a 6-month history of a non-healing genital ulcer. Examination revealed a solitary ulcer measuring 3cm x 2cm on the labia majora. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy revealed nests of malignant squamous epithelium with prominent central keratin pearls surrounded by a chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of squamous carcinoma of the vulva, and HPV 11 infection is not considered a risk factor.

Infection with HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, and 45 are known to be associated with the risk of the development of vulvar carcinoma. HPV 16 infection is the most common. HPV 6 and 11 cause most cases of genital warts but are seldom linked to cancer and are known as low-risk HPV.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequent vulvar carcinoma, followed by malignant melanoma. Patients present with pruritis and a visible lesion that may be ulcerated, bleeding, warty, raised, or pigmented. There may be other clinical entities, such as preinvasive neoplasia (vulval intraepithelial neoplasia - VIN), infection, chronic inflammatory disease, and granulomatous disease.

On histopathological examination, the tumor shows classic features of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, such as squamous cells, intercellular bridges, and eosinophilic keratin pearls. Nests of invasive tumor cells are surrounded by chronic inflammation.

Risk factors for vulvar carcinoma: 

  • Age: The risk of vulvar cancer increases with age; the highest incidence is seen in women over 70 years of age.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)- HPV 16 is the most commonly associated type, but HPV types 18, 31, 33, and 45 are also known risk factors.
  • HSV infection (usually in a smoker)
  • Smoking
  • Chronic immunosuppression - HIV infection, transplantation patients
  • Lichen sclerosus- chronic vulvar inflammatory disease and can be considered a precursor lesion, usually in older women
  • Other genital cancers: Women with cervical cancer might have a higher risk of vulvar cancer  
  • Progression from VIN

The images below show Stages IA, IB, 2, 3, 4A, and 4B of vulvar carcinoma in order:

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread

IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes

questions.text: In a family planning clinic, you see a flyer advertising the pills shown below as a method of contraception. Identify the true statement about it.

choices.text: Can be taken by diabetic women

questions.solution:
The true statement about desogestrel pills (synthetic progesterone-only pills) is that they can be taken by diabetic women. This is because they have minimal effects on carbohydrate metabolism.

Progesterone-only pills are also known as minipills. They are started 21 days postpartum and soon after an abortion. The woman needs to take precautions in the first 48 hours of the first cycle.

The mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills involves thickening of the cervical mucus that inhibits penetration of sperms (mainly), atrophy of the endometrium, and inhibition of ovulation.

Advantages of progesterone-only pills include:

  • Minimal or no effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • Do not cause or exacerbate hypertension 
  • Do not impair milk production, therefore suitable during lactation
  • Safe for women with a history of migraine headaches
  • Safe for smokers who are older than 35 years

Contraindications include abnormal uterine bleeding, breast cancer, hepatic cancer, pregnancy, and active severe liver disease. Additionally, synthetic progestogens like desogestrel are associated with a higher incidence of thromboembolism.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 20-year old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following vaccines is not protective against this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition in the image is condyloma acuminata (venereal warts) caused by infection with human papilloma virus 6 or 11. The Cervarix vaccine does not protect against it. Cervarix offers protection against HPV subtypes 16,18, which cause CIN and Ca cervix.

The image shows multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, as seen in condyloma acuminata. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They may be asymptomatic but can also cause discomfort, discharge, or bleeding. Treatment may include ablation, excision, or topical agents such as podophyllin and imiquimod.

The available vaccinations against HPV are summarized below.

Brand name Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
Characteristic and HPV subtypes Bivalent:16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58
Protects against: CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, CA cervix,  Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
Dose 0.5ml  0.5ml 0.5ml
Administration 0, 1, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6months, i.m
Administered gender Female and male Female and male Female and male
Ideal Age range: 11-12 years,9-26 years  11-12 years, 9-26 years for both male and female

Females:11-12 years, 9-26 years

Males:11-12 years

9-15 years - FDA approved

Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication, which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16,18,31,33,45,52,58.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for ovulation function. Which of the following is seen after the ovulation has occurred?

LH- Luteinizing hormone

choices.text: Growth of ovarian follicles seen on USG

questions.solution:
An increase in basal body temperature is seen after ovulation has occurred.

The basal body temperature (BBT) decreases by around 1/2°F at the time of ovulation and then increases by 1/2-1°F during the progestational half of the cycle. This occurs due to the thermogenic action of the hormone progesterone. When this is represented graphically, a biphasic pattern is observed and is strongly predictive of ovulation, as shown in the image below.

 

However, this method cannot accurately predict ovulation. It provides a retrospective diagnosis of ovulation and is not useful therapeutically.

Other options:

Option A:  Urinary LH peak (increase in LH) is usually seen 1 day prior to ovulation and is used to predict the time of ovulation. It is detected by daily monitoring of urinary LH levels and spans for about 48-50 hours.

Option C: Growth of ovarian follicles is seen on USG prior to ovulation. The follicle is observed to grow at the rate of 1-2 mm per day before follicular rupture, and ovulation occurs when it is 20 mm or more in size. This is a reliable and safe method of predicting ovulation.

Option D: The appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus, leading to the loss of fern pattern.

Positive fern test as seen before ovulation is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman who presented with abnormal uterine bleeding is scheduled for endometrial biopsy. In her case file, you see her transvaginal sonography report. What is the endometrial thickness you are expecting to see?
questions.solution:
In a postmenopausal woman with abnormal uterine bleeding, investigations like endometrial sampling is indicated when the endometrial thickness is >4 mm. Since the patient is posted for an endometrial biopsy, the thickness of her endometrium is likely to be more than 4 mm. 

Timing Endometrial thickness
Immediately after menstruation 1–2 mm
Early proliferative phase 5–7 mm
Secretory phase 7–16 mm
Preovulatory phase  up to 12 mm
Postmenopausal (Asymptomatic) <4 mm
Postmenopausal with bleeding; investigations should start when the thickness is >4 mm

An endometrial biopsy can be done by

  • Dilatation and curettage
  • Uterine cavity aspiration using a pipelle and endometrial sampling (office biopsy)

Indications for endometrial sampling:

  • Any woman aged >45 years with abnormal uterine bleeding
  • A woman aged <45 years with exposure to excessive estrogen, such as those with polycystic ovary disease, severe obesity, or tamoxifen treatment
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding
  • Transvaginal ultrasound showing an endometrial thickness of >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women

questions.text: In which of the following stages of puberty does estrogen not have a major role?
questions.solution:
Pubarche, or the development of pubic hair, is not mediated by estrogen.

In both sexes, adrenal androgen secretion is responsible for adrenarche—the development of axillary and pubic hair. The eventual phenotypical result of adrenarche is pubarche, increased oiliness of hair and skin, and acne.

Puberty refers to the period of transition from childhood to adult sexual maturation. On average, puberty typically begins between the ages of 8 and 13 years in females and 9 and 14 years in males. 

The following changes occur in puberty:

  • Thelarche refers to breast development, which signifies the start of puberty in girls. It is due to the action of estrogen and progesterone.
  • Pubarche occurs after thelarche, and refers to the appearance of pubic hair. Adrenarche refers to the increased secretion of adrenal androgens which leads to pubarche.
  • Growth spurt occurs due to a rise in sex steroids, which leads to an increase in growth hormone levels and IGF-1.
  • Menarche refers to the beginning of menstruation due to an increase in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).

questions.text: A young woman was diagnosed with a structural uterine abnormality by hysterosalpingography. Which two anomalies cannot be easily differentiated from each other by this investigation?
questions.solution:
Septate and bicornuate uterus are the two anomalies that cannot be easily differentiated from each other by hysterosalpingography (HSG). HSG provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour. 

A bicornuate uterus is characterized by two separate endometrial cavities, that may communicate with each other and a single uterine cervix. It is caused by the incomplete fusion of the müllerian ducts. Failure of fusion may extend to the cervix, resulting in a complete bicornuate uterus, or may be partial, causing a milder abnormality. 

On HSG, the bicornuate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle >105 degrees. However, MR imaging is necessary to define the external or fundal contour.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity. It is caused by the failure of the medial segments of the müllerian ducts to regress, creating a permanent septum within the uterine cavity. The septum can project minimally from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os. 

On HSG, the intercornual angle is <75 degrees (as shown in the image below). 

Unfortunately, the majority of angles of divergence between the horns fall between 75 and 105 degrees leading to overlapping between the two anomalies on HSG.

Transvaginal 3D ultrasonography (3D TV USG) is the best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus and is recommended for the assessment of patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Pelvic MRI without contrast also provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV US is not possible as in the case of virgins.

Other options:

Uterus Didelphys: A didelphic uterus is characterized by two separate uterine horns, each with an endometrial cavity and cervix. It results from the failure of the fusion of the paired müllerian ducts.

Arcuate uterus: It is characterised by minimal fundal cavity indentation or a slight midline septum within a broad fundus. 

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

  • Malpresentation

  • Preterm delivery

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida presented with right flank pain. MRI evaluation revealed a solid, enhancing  5×13×7 cm right ovarian mass. Salpingo-oophorectomy was successfully done and microscopic examination of the tumor cells showed a close resemblance to primordial germ cells. It was also noticed that the tumor appeared histologically identical to a testicular seminoma. Which of the following is not secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
An ovarian tumor in a young woman which consists of primordial germ cells and is histologically similar to seminoma suggests a diagnosis of an ovarian dysgerminoma. It does not secrete sex hormones.

Dysgerminoma usually arises in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumour diagnosed during pregnancy.

The tumor is neutral and does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and β-hCG. Serum LDH and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms that do not have the potential for further differentiation. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. 

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors
