Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.solution:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy.

Chemoradiation is the mainstay of treatment of stage III and IV endometrial cancers. They are treated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. 

Other options: 

Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature.

Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.

Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with an obstetric code of P3L3 came with complaints of heaviness in her pelvic region. The uterine prolapse was similar to the illustration given below. What is the degree of prolapse?
questions.solution:
The given condition is a second-degree uterine prolapse, where the cervix descends to the level of the vulva as seen in the image above. 

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of supports. It is classified based on compartment of descent. 

It has multifactorial etiology. It is thought that combinations of anatomical, physiological, genetic, lifestyle, and reproductive factors are responsible for pelvic floor dysfunction. However, pregnancy, vaginal delivery, prior pelvic surgeries, or conditions associated with sustained episodes of increased intraabdominal pressure increase the risk of developing pelvic organ prolapse. 

Patients may be asymptomatic. Those who have symptoms may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. It may cause bladder outlet obstruction, affect sexual activity, body image, and quality of life. 

The following image depicts the degrees of prolapse:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of a constant leakage of urine and dysuria even after undergoing fistula repair surgery for vesicovaginal fistula. You decide to attempt a second fistula repair surgery. In order to perform the second surgery, you would counsel the patient to wait for at least
questions.solution:
In order to perform the second surgery, you should counsel the patient to wait for at least 3 months.

The given scenario is suggestive of failed surgery. If the fistula repair fails, one should wait for at least 3 months before attempting a second repair.

Patients usually present with constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). The constant leakage of urine may lead to excoriation of genital regions. The fistula located at the vaginal vault post-hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist suspects endometriosis. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the investigation that will be most helpful in the diagnosis is laparoscopy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary, followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/tattooing seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst, low level echoes or clumps of high-density level echoes representing clots.

The image below shows powder burns/tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient presented with excessive, painless bleeding per vaginum for the past 8 days. This episode was preceded by two months of amenorrhea. The ultrasound revealed thickened endometrium, with thin slender polypi projecting into the uterine cavity, and associated myometrial hyperplasia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Endometrial sampling is mandatory in evaluating the disease
The ovaries associated with this condition may have a cyst
Endometrial histology shows the presence of cork screw glands
This type of AUB is not related to parity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica, and the corkscrew glands are not seen in this condition.

The endometrium shows characteristic cystic glandular hyperplasia, which appears as a swiss cheese pattern. The second feature is the absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands (as the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium).

Metropathia haemorrhagica, is a specialized form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding, is seen in women aged 40 to 45 years.

Typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

The uterus is slightly bulky, uniformly enlarged and the uterine wall shows a mild degree of myohyperplasia, measuring up to 2.5 cm. The endometrium is thick, polypoidal, and thin slender polyps project into the uterine cavity. Corpus luteum is absent and one or both ovaries may contain a cyst, not larger than 5 cm.

questions.text: What is the most common type of vaginal cancer likely to be seen in a woman with a history of intrauterine di-ethyl stilbesterol exposure?
questions.solution:
Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history of intrauterine DES exposure. 

It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice. 

The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear cell adenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient had complaints of post-coital bleeding with leucorrhoea. An initial visual inspection with acetic acid showed an abnormal finding, which, when followed by a colposcopic guided biopsy of the cervix,  had the malignant cells occupying the lower 50% to 75% of the epithelial thickness. She wishes for conservative treatment, as she has not completed her family. Which of the following might be offered considering the future pregnancy?

choices.text: Needle excision of the transformation zone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histologic finding are suggestive of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL/CIN II) of the cervix. An ideal procedure to be performed in this patient, anticipating the future pregnancy would be laser ablation.

This is because ablative techniques do not result in future pregnancy complications.

Techniques involving the excision of abnormal tissue such as

  • Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LLETZ)
  • Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP)
  • Needle Excision of the Transformation Zone (NETZ)
  • Cold knife conization
  • Laser conization

result in the stenosis of the cervix, abortion, and premature labour. Hence avoid in female patients who desire for childbirth in the near future

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility, and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium. 

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

Proliferative phase

  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiralled.
  • The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium

Secretory phase 

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)
  • Corkscrew-shaped glands

The image below shows secretory endometrium

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: A menopausal woman presents with complaints of hot flushes. Which of the following neurotransmitters are responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine and serotonin are responsible for hot flushes in menopausal women.

A fall in the level of estrogen causes a reduction in hypothalamic endorphins. This causes a release of more norepinephrine and serotonin, which lower the set point in the thermoregulatory nucleus. As a result, the heat-loss mechanism is triggered by even subtle changes in core body temperature.

Risk factors for hot flushes:

  • Low estradiol levels
  • High BMI
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Surgical menopause has increased risk
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • History of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)
  • Depression.

questions.text: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of _______.
questions.solution:
The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of inhibin secreted by Sertoli cells.

GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone). FSH acts on Sertoli cells while LH triggers testosterone secretion by the Leydig cells. Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B which in turn inhibits FSH but stimulate LH secretion.

questions.text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
In low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) will be <1 ng/ml. 

AMH is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of the primordial follicle of the ovary. It helps in oocyte maturation and mono-follicular development. AMH is also used in assessing ovarian reserve.

AMH levels in ng/ml Interpretation
2–6.8 Normal
<1 Poor ovarian reserve
>10

PCOD

Hyperstimulation syndrome

In women, AMH is always absent during embryogenesis and is secreted by the granulosa cells after puberty. It helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. Estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in female infertility and secondary amenorrhoea.

In men, AMH starts to be secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testes by the 7th week of intrauterine life. It continues until puberty. It inhibits the development of the Müllerian system. The absence of AMH results in the development of hermaphroditism.

questions.text: The following hysterosalpingogram indicates
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography can be performed alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

The above image is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions found with Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: Metrorrhagia refers to _______

choices.text: Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding

questions.solution:
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding are referred to as metrorrhagia.

Menstrual cycle irregularities are as follows:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs irregularly and at frequent intervals.
  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea indicates frequent episodes of menstruation that occur at intervals of 21 days or lesser. 
  • Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>5 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation is the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding is vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: Halban's disease is ______

choices.text: Irregular shedding  due to persistent corpus luteum

questions.solution:
• Halbans disease is irregular shedding due to persistent corpus luteum.
  • It is rare and usually self-limiting. 
  • Menstruation occurs on time and is prolonged but not heavy.

questions.text: An increase in which of the following is spasmodic pain during dysmenorrhoea attributed to?
questions.solution:
Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions occuring due to increased PGF2α. This is secreted under the effect of progesterone.

Progesterone is secreted after ovulation by the corpus luteum. Hence, in anovulatory cycles, menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of dull aching pain in the lower abdomen for the past 8 months. There is no clinical evidence of any pelvic pathology. She says the pain decreases on lying down and increases on walking, bending, and standing. You diagnose her with having chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Which of the following is false regarding this syndrome?

choices.text: Conscious pain mapping is not useful in diagnosis

questions.solution:
Conscious pain mapping is a useful investigation in the diagnosis of chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Chronic pelvic pain (CPP) refers to acyclical pelvic pain of more than 6 months duration. 

Chronic pelvic pain syndrome is a condition characterized by CPP not associated with any clinical evidence of pelvic pathology. It possibly occurs because of dilated pelvic veins. And, hence, shifting the location of pain with body movement is characteristic of this syndrome. It is associated with congestive dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital ache, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Doppler ultrasound and venography help in the diagnosis. Conscious pain mapping at laparoscopy under local anesthesia is useful in deciding the cause and location of chronic pain. This improves diagnostic accuracy.

Treatment comprises progestogen therapy. Progestogens, by their anti-estrogenic effect, constrict the veins, reduce blood flow, and suppress ovulation.

questions.text: You are inserting Nova-T in a patient for spacing of births. This device contains______.
questions.solution:
Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan.

In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, they are of various types:

  • Copper T 380 A
  • Multiload copper 250
  • Copper T 200
  • Copper 7
  • Copper T 220
  • Nova-T

They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 years.

questions.text: An actress wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. However, she is concerned about the resulting scars on her abdomen. Which of the following methods of sterilization would best suit her case?
questions.solution:
Essure would best suit the actress as it is done through the hysteroscopic method, thus, avoiding abdominal scar.

The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). In the inner coil, there is a layer of polyethylene terephthalate fibers that occludes the fallopian tube by initiating a benign local fibrous tissue growth. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. Tubal blockage can be confirmed 3 months later by hysterosalpingography. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and that it can be done under local anesthesia.

However, disadvantages include:

  • Hysteroscopy is required to insert the Essure device
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage after 3 months
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube 
  • The failure rate is 3.5%

Other options

Option A: Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.

Option B:  In Madlener's procedure a loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a non-absorbable suture.

Option D: In the Pomeroy procedure the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A woman presents with cyclical hematuria 8 months after an emergency cesarean section was done for non-progress of labor. There is no urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Other causes of cyclical hematuria can be intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) perforation into the bladder or bladder endometriosis. True pathology can be confirmed by cystoscopy.

Treatment:

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization can close the fistula. 
  • Abdominal repair using omental or gracilis graft is done if the prolonged catheterization fails.

Methylene blue swab test:

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

Other options:

Option A: In a vesicovaginal fistula, the main complaint will be constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). It usually follows difficult childbirth. A positive methylene blue test confirms the diagnosis. 

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Option D: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman presents to you with complaints of genuine stress urinary incontinence(GSI). Investigation revealed loss of posterior urethrovesical angle and urethral hypermobility with normal intrinsic sphincter activity. Identify the type of GSI seen in this patient from the surgical procedure point of view?
questions.solution:
Type 2 GSI has been described in the above patient.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction

Considering the surgical procedure that should be done, GSI is classified into three types:

  • Type I: GSI occurs due to loss of posterior urethrovesical angle alone.
  • Type II: Loss of posterior urethrovesical angle as well as urethral hypermobility.
  • Type III: It is due to intrinsic sphincter deficiency.

Grading of GSI:

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walk, going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Tests done for GSI(Genuine stress incontinence) are:

  1. Stress test
  2. Cotton swab stick test
  3. Marshall and Bonney test
  4. Urethroscopy
  5. Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry, etc

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with irregular periods, hirsutism, and infertility. Her ultrasound scan revealed the finding shown in the image below. Which of the following options is not correct regarding the USG criteria for this condition?

choices.text: At least 10 follicles should be present for diagnosis
Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in size
Ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on OCPs

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound shows multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern, which is a feature of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). At least 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm should be seen on an ultrasound.

 USG Criteria: 

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • ≥12 follicles(Rotterdam criteria)/ ≥20 follicles(New criteria) each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume ≥10 ml
  • These ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on combined oral pills, as these pills alter the ovarian morphology.
  • A single ovary meeting these criteria is enough to diagnose PCOD.

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology, 2003):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovarian syndrome:

National Institute of Health (NIH, 1990):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation

Androgen excess and PCOS society (AE-PCOS):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

Necklace appearance of right ovary on USG in PCOD:

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to grade hirsutism using the modified Ferriman Gallwey scoring method in a 25-year-old female patient. After examining all the areas, you assign a score of 3 for each area. The total score in this patient is found to be _______
questions.solution:
The total Modified Ferriman Gallwey score in the above patient is found to be 27.

Modified Ferriman Gallwey scoring system:

  • It is used to quantify the degree of hirsutism
  • In this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed in nine body areas (Therefore the total score in the above patient is 27) and a score of 0 to 4 is given for each area. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. 
  • The following are the nine areas, which are used to assess hirsutism,
    • Upper lip
    • Chin
    • Chest
    • Upper abdomen
    • Lower abdomen
    • Thighs
    • Back
    • Arms and
    • Buttocks
  • The maximum score is 36
    • A score of 8 to 15 indicates mild hirsutism
    • A score greater than 15 indicates moderate or severe hirsutism.

questions.text: A pap smear was done on a 39-year-old woman as a part of a routine health checkup. The cytology picture is shown below. The cell marked A in the smear is _______.
questions.solution:
The cell marked A in the smear is a superficial cell which is an estrogen-dominant cell. These are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus seen predominantly in the first half of the menstrual cycle.

  • Intermediate cells: Progesterone dominant cells which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than that of superficial cells. These are seen in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
  • Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the postpartum period.
  • Human papilloma infected cells: Shows koilocytes. These cells have hyperchromatic enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halo.

The cytology image of a normal Pap smear is shown below.

The koilocytes(right side) compared to normal Pap smear(left side).

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented to the emergency department with signs of shock. Upon further investigations, a diagnosis of a ruptured tubo-ovarian mass was made. At what stage of pelvic inflammatory disease is she in?
questions.solution:
The ruptured tubo-ovarian mass belongs to stage IV of pelvic inflammatory diseases. It usually presents with a sudden worsening of the patient's condition.

Tubo ovarian abscess is a complication of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It can be unilateral or bilateral and is characterized by dull or sharp abdominal pain. It is associated with other features like fever and an adnexal mass. On auscultation, a frictional rub can be heard throughout all quadrants of the abdomen which can be suggestive of a ruptured ovarian abscess. 

Treatment involves the administration of parenteral antibiotics till the patient has been afebrile for at least 24 hours. Following this, oral doxycycline with either metronidazole or clindamycin is given for 14 days. Ruptured abscess is treated surgically.

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis
